item.title: Good data visualization
item.description: Whether data visualization is good depend on the aims of plotting. Usually one people plot for two reasons, or for two purposes. One is exploratory and the other is explanation. For exploratory, one good plot help to creat connection among different subjects, help to broad mind on the research work. For explanation, good plot reveal and explain our results. In most cases, we plot for both reasons.

item.title: scraping data from wiki to analyze olympic medal
item.description: Today I learn Edwin Thoen from R-blogger. The topic is how to scrape the data from wikepedia and tidy the data in a format in which they can be analyzed. Thank Edwin for sharing the code. scrape data from website I use rvest and tidy package. library("rvest") library(tidyverse) library(stringr) Olympics_2018_wiki <- read_html("https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_2018_Winter_Olympics_medal_winners") sports <- html_nodes(Olympics_2018_wiki, "h2") %>% html_text() sports %>% head(3) ## [1] "Alpine skiing[edit]" "Biathlon[edit]" "Bobsleigh[edit]" html_text is used to convert the xml nodes to regular R characters.

item.title: How to merge to graph using same y axis
item.description: In case of that I want to plot several graphs, and the datasets are same and variables are same. How to make it in a compact way, such as I want them share the same y-axis and distinct x-axis, or verse visa. Or I treat X variables in different ways, log and 1/x.
